awd_titl_txt: RTG: Algebraic Geometry, Applied Algebra, and Number Theory at the University of Wisconsin
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a mathematics research training group in the areas of number theory, applied algebra, and algebraic geometry. The research group activities, centered on training through research involvement for students and postdoctoral associates, include collaborative undergraduate research labs (CURLs), a summer enhancement program for training new U.S. graduate students, and miniconferences and graduate student research conferences. Postdoctoral associates receive substantial mentoring to ensure their continued professional development, and graduate students play a central role in the research activity. Graduate students mentor undergraduates in CURL participation, spend semesters in the new Wisconsin Institutes for Discovery, and receive special fellowships at the critical juncture of starting a thesis.

The Algebraic Geometry, Applied Algebra, and Number Theory Group at Wisconsin has seen a recent influx of faculty with substantial experience in mentoring students. The group will develop a unique, ground-breaking program in Applied Algebra, in conjunction with the multidisciplinary Wisconsin Institutes for Discovery, providing broad training in the education of students and postdocs for diverse careers in academia and industry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RES TRAINING GROUPS IN THE MATH SCIENCES

por.por_cntn:
The major impacts of this grant are through research training and professional development at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels.  In particular, the grant had a major impact on the career trajectories of hundreds of individuals.  

At the undergraduate level, the grant supported a unique course where undergraduates had the opportunity to engage in collaborative mathematical research.  While such experiences are common in some fields, they are very rare within mathematics as most professors’ research programs do not have opportunities for undergraduate involvement, and so this course allowed many undergraduates to engage with research and determine if a research-based career in the mathematical sciences was a viable and appealing path for them. Many of these students went on to graduate programs.

At the graduate level, the grant supported many PhD students as they launched their research careers. The support came in the form of: targeted fellowships for graduate students at key moments in their development of a research program; travel support for graduate students to engage with researchers across the country and around the world; and professional development activities targeted at finding jobs throughout academia and industry. Many of these PhD students have gone on to top postdoctoral and tenure track positions within academia, and to jobs in technology and industry.  Many also contributed to the impact on undergraduate research experiences, acting as mentors.
At the postdoctoral level, the most significant impact is through the career development of several individuals who have gone on to jobs in research and industry.  These researchers also contributed to the research training of the graduate and undergraduate students through their seminars, collaborations, workshops organized, and more.
In addition, the grant helped broaden participation in the mathematical sciences by helping advance the research careers of a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students.

Last Modified: 03/26/2022
Modified by: Andrei H Caldararu
